Rebecca MacKinnon of the Wikimedia Foundation said that such checks would run counter to the website's commitment to minimal data collection on its contributors and readers.[208] Sexism Main article: Gender bias on Wikipedia Wikipedia was described in 2015 as harboring a battleground culture of sexism and harassment.[209][210] The perceived tolerance of abusive language was a reason put forth in 2013 for the gender gap in Wikipedia editorship.[211] Edit-a-thons have been held to encourage female editors and increase the coverage of women's topics.[212] In May 2018
column597: a Wikipedia editor rejected a submitted article about Donna Strickland due to lack of coverage in the media.[W 63][213] Five months later
column598: Strickland won a Nobel Prize in Physics "for groundbreaking inventions in the field of laser physics"
column599: becoming the third woman to ever receive the award.[213][214] Prior to winning the award
column600: Strickland's only mention on Wikipedia was in the article about her collaborator and co-winner of the award Gérard Mourou.[213] Her exclusion from Wikipedia led to accusations of sexism
column601: but Corinne Purtill writing for Quartz argued that "it's also a pointed lesson in the hazards of gender bias in media
column602: and of the broader consequences of underrepresentation."[215] Purtill attributes the issue to the gender bias in media coverage.[215] A comprehensive 2008 survey
column604: by Julia B. Bear of Stony Brook University's College of Business and Benjamin Collier of Carnegie Mellon University found significant gender differences in confidence in expertise
column606: and response to critical feedback. "Women reported less confidence in their expertise
column607: expressed greater discomfort with editing (which typically involves conflict)
column608: and reported more negative responses to critical feedback compared to men."[216] Operation Wikimedia Foundation and affiliate movements Main article: Wikimedia Foundation Katherine Maher
column609: the third executive director of Wikimedia
column610: served from 2016 to 2021. Wikipedia is hosted and funded by the Wikimedia Foundation
column611: a non-profit organization which also operates Wikipedia-related projects such as Wiktionary and Wikibooks.[W 64] The foundation relies on public contributions and grants to fund its mission.[217][W 65] The foundation's 2020 Internal Revenue Service Form 990 shows revenue of $124.6 million and expenses of almost $112.2 million
column612: with assets of about $191.2 million and liabilities of almost $11 million.[W 66] In May 2014
column613: Wikimedia Foundation named Lila Tretikov as its second executive director
column614: taking over for Sue Gardner.[W 67] The Wall Street Journal reported on May 1
column616: that Tretikov's information technology background from her years at University of California offers Wikipedia an opportunity to develop in more concentrated directions guided by her often repeated position statement that
column619: wants to be free."[218][219] The same Wall Street Journal article reported these directions of development according to an interview with spokesman Jay Walsh of Wikimedia
column620: who "said Tretikov would address that issue (paid advocacy) as a priority. 'We are really pushing toward more transparency ... We are reinforcing that paid advocacy is not welcome.' Initiatives to involve greater diversity of contributors
column622: new geo-location tools to find local content more easily
column623: and more tools for users in the second and third world are also priorities"
column624: Walsh said.[218] Following the departure of Tretikov from Wikipedia due to issues concerning the use of the "superprotection" feature which some language versions of Wikipedia have adopted
column625: [W 68] Katherine Maher became the third executive director of the Wikimedia Foundation in June 2016.[W 69] Maher stated that one of her priorities would be the issue of editor harassment endemic to Wikipedia as identified by the Wikipedia board in December. She said to Bloomberg Businessweek regarding the harassment issue that: "It establishes a sense within the community that this is a priority ... [and that correction requires that] it has to be more than words."[122] Maher served as executive director until April 2021.[220] Maryana Iskander was named the incoming CEO in September 2021
column626: and took over that role in January 2022. She stated that one of her focuses would be increasing diversity in the Wikimedia community.[221] Wikipedia is also supported by many organizations and groups that are affiliated with the Wikimedia Foundation but independently-run
column627: called Wikimedia movement affiliates. These include Wikimedia chapters (which are national or sub-national organizations
column628: such as Wikimedia Deutschland and Wikimedia France)
column629: thematic organizations (such as Amical Wikimedia for the Catalan language community)
column630: and user groups. These affiliates participate in the promotion
column632: and funding of Wikipedia.[W 70] Software operations and support See also: MediaWiki The operation of Wikipedia depends on MediaWiki
column634: free and open source wiki software platform written in PHP and built upon the MySQL database system.[W 71] The software incorporates programming features such as a macro language
column637: and URL redirection.[W 72] MediaWiki is licensed under the GNU General Public License (GPL) and it is used by all Wikimedia projects
column638: as well as many other wiki projects.[W 71][W 73] Originally
column639: Wikipedia ran on UseModWiki written in Perl by Clifford Adams (Phase I)
column640: which initially required CamelCase for article hyperlinks; the present double bracket style was incorporated later.[W 74] Starting in January 2002 (Phase II)
column641: Wikipedia began running on a PHP wiki engine with a MySQL database; this software was custom-made for Wikipedia by Magnus Manske. The Phase II software was repeatedly modified to accommodate the exponentially increasing demand. In July 2002 (Phase III)
column642: Wikipedia shifted to the third-generation software
column644: originally written by Lee Daniel Crocker. Several MediaWiki extensions are installed to extend the functionality of the MediaWiki software.[W 75] In April 2005
column645: a Lucene extension[W 76][W 77] was added to MediaWiki's built-in search and Wikipedia switched from MySQL to Lucene for searching. Lucene was later replaced by CirrusSearch which is based on Elasticsearch.[W 78] In July 2013
column647: a WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) extension
column649: was opened to public use.[222][223][224] It was met with much rejection and criticism
column650: and was described as "slow and buggy".[225] The feature was changed from opt-out to opt-in afterward.[W 79] Automated editing Main article: Wikipedia bots Computer programs called bots have often been used to perform simple and repetitive tasks
column651: such as correcting common misspellings and stylistic issues
column652: or to start articles such as geography entries in a standard format from statistical data.[W 80][226][227] One controversial contributor
column654: created articles with his bot Lsjbot
column655: which was reported to create up to 10
column656: 000 articles on the Swedish Wikipedia on certain days.[228] Additionally
column657: there are bots designed to automatically notify editors when they make common editing errors (such as unmatched quotes or unmatched parentheses).[W 81] Edits falsely identified by bots as the work of a banned editor can be restored by other editors. An anti-vandal bot is programmed to detect and revert vandalism quickly.[226] Bots are able to indicate edits from particular accounts or IP address ranges
column658: as occurred at the time of the shooting down of the MH17 jet in July 2014 when it was reported that edits were made via IPs controlled by the Russian government.[229] Bots on Wikipedia must be approved before activation.[W 82] According to Andrew Lih
column659: the current expansion of Wikipedia to millions of articles would be difficult to envision without the use of such bots.[230] Hardware operations and support As of 2021
column660: [update] page requests are first passed to a front-end layer of Varnish caching servers and back-end layer caching is done by Apache Traffic Server.[W 83] Requests that cannot be served from the Varnish cache are sent to load-balancing servers running the Linux Virtual Server software
column661: which in turn pass them to one of the Apache web servers for page rendering from the database.[W 83] The web servers deliver pages as requested
column662: performing page rendering for all the language editions of Wikipedia. To increase speed further
column663: rendered pages are cached in a distributed memory cache until invalidated
column664: allowing page rendering to be skipped entirely for most common page accesses.[231] Overview of system architecture as of August 2022[update] Wikipedia currently runs on dedicated clusters of Linux servers running the Debian operating system.[W 84] By January 22
column666: Wikipedia had migrated its primary data center to an Equinix facility in Ashburn
column668: Wikipedia installed a caching cluster in an Equinix facility in Singapore
column669: the first of its kind in Asia.[W 86] In 2022
column670: a caching data center was opened in Marseille
column672: [update] caching clusters are located in Amsterdam
column675: and Marseille.[W 25][W 88] Internal research and operational development Following growing amounts of incoming donations in 2013 exceeding seven digits
column676: [38] the Foundation has reached a threshold of assets which qualify its consideration under the principles of industrial organization economics to indicate the need for the re-investment of donations into the internal research and development of the Foundation.[233] Two projects of such internal research and development have been the creation of a Visual Editor and the "Thank" tab in the edit history
column677: which were developed to improve issues of editor attrition.[38][225] The estimates for reinvestment by industrial organizations into internal research and development was studied by Adam Jaffe
column678: who recorded that the range of 4% to 25% annually was to be recommended
column679: with high-end technology requiring the higher level of support for internal reinvestment.[234] At the 2013 level of contributions for Wikimedia presently documented as 45 million dollars
column680: [W 89] the computed budget level recommended by Jaffe for reinvestment into internal research and development is between 1.8 million and 11.3 million dollars annually.[234] In 2019
column681: the level of contributions were reported by the Wikimedia Foundation as being at $120 million annually
column682: [W 90] updating the Jaffe estimates for the higher level of support to between $3.08 million and $19.2 million annually.[234] Internal news publications Main article: The Signpost Multiple Wikimedia projects have internal news publications. Wikimedia's online newspaper The Signpost was founded in 2005 by Michael Snow
column683: a Wikipedia administrator who would join the Wikimedia Foundation's board of trustees in 2008.[235][236] The publication covers news and events from the English Wikipedia
column685: and Wikipedia's sister projects.[W 91] The Wikipedia Library For information for Wikipedia editors
column686: see Wikipedia:The Wikipedia Library. Wikipedia Library The Wikipedia Library is a resource for Wikipedia editors which provides free access to a wide range of digital publications
column687: so that they can consult and cite these while editing the encyclopedia.[237][238] Over 60 publishers have partnered with The Wikipedia Library to provide access to their resources: when ICE Publishing joined in 2020
column688: a spokesman said "By enabling free access to our content for Wikipedia editors
column689: we hope to further the research community's resources – creating and updating Wikipedia entries on civil engineering which are read by thousands of monthly readers."[239] Access to content "Accessing Wikipedia" redirects here. For our accessibility guidelines
column690: see Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Accessibility. Content licensing When the project was started in 2001
column691: all text in Wikipedia was covered by the GNU Free Documentation License (GFDL)
column692: a copyleft license permitting the redistribution
column694: and commercial use of content while authors retain copyright of their work.[W 24] The GFDL was created for software manuals that come with free software programs licensed under the GPL. This made it a poor choice for a general reference work: for example
column695: the GFDL requires the reprints of materials from Wikipedia to come with a full copy of the GFDL text.[240] In December 2002
column696: the Creative Commons license was released; it was specifically designed for creative works in general
column697: not just for software manuals. The Wikipedia project sought the switch to the Creative Commons.[W 92] Because the GFDL and Creative Commons were incompatible
column699: following the request of the project
column700: the Free Software Foundation (FSF) released a new version of the GFDL designed specifically to allow Wikipedia to relicense its content to CC BY-SA by August 1
column702: Wikipedia and its sister projects held a community-wide referendum which decided the switch in June 2009.[W 94][W 95][W 96][W 97] The handling of media files (e.g. image files) varies across language editions. Some language editions
column704: include non-free image files under fair use doctrine
column705: [W 98] while the others have opted not to
column706: in part because of the lack of fair use doctrines in their home countries (e.g. in Japanese copyright law). Media files covered by free content licenses (e.g. Creative Commons' CC BY-SA) are shared across language editions via Wikimedia Commons repository
column707: a project operated by the Wikimedia Foundation.[W 99] Wikipedia's accommodation of varying international copyright laws regarding images has led some to observe that its photographic coverage of topics lags behind the quality of the encyclopedic text.[241] The Wikimedia Foundation is not a licensor of content on Wikipedia or its related projects but merely a hosting service for contributors to and licensors of Wikipedia
column708: a position which was successfully defended in 2004 in a court in France.[242][243] Methods of access Because Wikipedia content is distributed under an open license
column709: anyone can reuse or re-distribute it at no charge.[W 100] The content of Wikipedia has been published in many forms
column711: outside the Wikipedia website. Thousands of "mirror sites" exist that republish content from Wikipedia; two prominent ones that also include content from other reference sources are Reference.com and Answers.com.[244][245] Another example is Wapedia
column712: which began to display Wikipedia content in a mobile-device-friendly format before Wikipedia itself did.[W 101] Some web search engines make special use of Wikipedia content when displaying search results: examples include Microsoft Bing (via technology gained from Powerset)[246] and DuckDuckGo. Collections of Wikipedia articles have been published on optical discs. An English version released in 2006 contained about 2
column713: 000 articles.[W 102] The Polish-language version from 2006 contains nearly 240
column715: [W 103] the German-language version from 2007/2008 contains over 620
column717: [W 104] and the Spanish-language version from 2011 contains 886
column720: the Wikipedia series of CDs / DVDs produced by Wikipedia and SOS Children
column721: is a free selection from Wikipedia designed for education towards children eight to seventeen.[W 106] There have been efforts to put a select subset of Wikipedia's articles into printed book form.[247][W 107] Since 2009
column722: tens of thousands of print-on-demand books that reproduced English
column725: and French Wikipedia articles have been produced by the American company Books LLC and by three Mauritian subsidiaries of the German publisher VDM.[248] The website DBpedia
column727: extracts data from the infoboxes and category declarations of the English-language Wikipedia.[249] Wikimedia has created the Wikidata project with a similar objective of storing the basic facts from each page of Wikipedia and other Wikimedia Foundation projects and make it available in a queryable semantic format
column729: [update] it has over 101 million items.[W 109] WikiReader is a dedicated reader device that contains an offline copy of Wikipedia
column730: which was launched by OpenMoko and first released in 2009.[W 110] Obtaining the full contents of Wikipedia for reuse presents challenges
column731: since direct cloning via a web crawler is discouraged.[W 111] Wikipedia publishes "dumps" of its contents
column732: but these are text-only; as of 2023
column733: [update] there is no dump available of Wikipedia's images.[W 112] Wikimedia Enterprise is a for-profit solution to this.[250] Several languages of Wikipedia also maintain a reference desk
column734: where volunteers answer questions from the general public. According to a study by Pnina Shachaf in the Journal of Documentation
column735: the quality of the Wikipedia reference desk is comparable to a standard library reference desk
column736: with an accuracy of 55 percent.[251] Mobile access See also: List of Wikipedia mobile applications and Help:Mobile access A mobile version showing the English Wikipedia's Main Page on October 2
column737: 2024 Wikipedia's original medium was for users to read and edit content using any standard web browser through a fixed Internet connection. Although Wikipedia content has been accessible through the mobile web since July 2013
column738: The New York Times on February 9
column741: deputy director of the Wikimedia Foundation
column742: stating that the transition of internet traffic from desktops to mobile devices was significant and a cause for concern and worry. The article in The New York Times reported the comparison statistics for mobile edits stating that
column743: "Only 20 percent of the readership of the English-language Wikipedia comes via mobile devices
column744: a figure substantially lower than the percentage of mobile traffic for other media sites
column745: many of which approach 50 percent. And the shift to mobile editing has lagged even more." In 2014 The New York Times reported that Möller has assigned "a team of 10 software developers focused on mobile"
column746: out of a total of approximately 200 employees working at the Wikimedia Foundation. One principal concern cited by The New York Times for the "worry" is for Wikipedia to effectively address attrition issues with the number of editors which the online encyclopedia attracts to edit and maintain its content in a mobile access environment.[45] By 2023
column747: the Wikimedia Foundation's staff had grown to over 700 employees.[7] Access to Wikipedia from mobile phones was possible as early as 2004
column749: via the Wapedia service.[W 101] In June 2007
column751: an official website for wireless devices. In 2009
column752: a newer mobile service was officially released
column754: which caters to more advanced mobile devices such as the iPhone
column756: or WebOS-based devices.[W 113] Several other methods of mobile access to Wikipedia have emerged since. Many devices and applications optimize or enhance the display of Wikipedia content for mobile devices
column757: while some also incorporate additional features such as use of Wikipedia metadata like geoinformation.[252][253] The Android app for Wikipedia was released in January 2012
column760: scoring over four of a possible five in a poll of approximately 200
column761: 000 users downloading from Google.[W 114][W 115] The version for iOS was released on April 3
column763: to similar reviews.[W 116] Wikipedia Zero was an initiative of the Wikimedia Foundation to expand the reach of the encyclopedia to the developing countries by partnering with mobile operators to allow free access.[W 117][254] It was discontinued in February 2018 due to lack of participation from mobile operators.[W 117] Andrew Lih and Andrew Brown both maintain editing Wikipedia with smartphones is difficult and this discourages new potential contributors.[255][256] Lih states that the number of Wikipedia editors has been declining after several years
column764: [255] and Tom Simonite of MIT Technology Review claims the bureaucratic structure and rules are a factor in this. Simonite alleges some Wikipedians use the labyrinthine rules and guidelines to dominate others and those editors have a vested interest in keeping the status quo.[38] Lih alleges there is a serious disagreement among existing contributors on how to resolve this. Lih fears for Wikipedia's long-term future while Brown fears problems with Wikipedia will remain and rival encyclopedias will not replace it.[255][256] Chinese access Access to Wikipedia has been blocked in mainland China since May 2015.[16][257][258] This was done after Wikipedia started to use HTTPS encryption
column765: which made selective censorship more difficult.[259] Cultural influence Trusted source to combat fake news In 2017–18
column766: after a barrage of false news reports
column767: both Facebook and YouTube announced they would rely on Wikipedia to help their users evaluate reports and reject false news.[13][14] Noam Cohen
column768: writing in The Washington Post states
column769: "YouTube's reliance on Wikipedia to set the record straight builds on the thinking of another fact-challenged platform
column771: which announced last year that Wikipedia would help its users root out 'fake news'."[14][260] Readership In February 2014
column772: The New York Times reported that Wikipedia was ranked fifth globally among all websites
column773: stating "With 18 billion page views and nearly 500 million unique visitors a month
column777: the largest with 1.2 billion unique visitors."[45] However
column778: its ranking dropped to 13th globally by June 2020 due mostly to a rise in popularity of Chinese websites for online shopping.[261] The website has since recovered its ranking as of April 2022.[262] In addition to logistic growth in the number of its articles
column779: [W 118] Wikipedia has steadily gained status as a general reference website since its inception in 2001.[263] The number of readers of Wikipedia worldwide reached 365 million at the end of 2009.[W 119] The Pew Internet and American Life project found that one third of US Internet users consulted Wikipedia.[264] In 2011
column780: Business Insider gave Wikipedia a valuation of $4 billion if it ran advertisements.[265] According to "Wikipedia Readership Survey 2011"
column781: the average age of Wikipedia readers is 36
column782: with a rough parity between genders. Almost half of Wikipedia readers visit the site more than five times a month
column783: and a similar number of readers specifically look for Wikipedia in search engine results. About 47 percent of Wikipedia readers do not realize that Wikipedia is a non-profit organization.[W 120] As of February 2023
column784: [update] Wikipedia attracts around 2 billion unique devices monthly
column785: with the English Wikipedia receiving 10 billion pageviews each month.[W 1] COVID-19 pandemic Main article: Wikipedia coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic During the COVID-19 pandemic
column786: Wikipedia's coverage of the pandemic and fight against misinformation received international media attention
column787: and brought an increase in Wikipedia readership overall.[266][267][268][269] Noam Cohen wrote in Wired that Wikipedia's effort to combat misinformation related to the pandemic was different from other major websites
column790: Facebook and the others can learn to address misinformation more effectively
column791: Wikipedia will remain the last best place on the Internet."[267] In October 2020
column792: the World Health Organization announced they were freely licensing its infographics and other materials on Wikimedia projects.[270] There were nearly 7
column793: 000 COVID-19 related Wikipedia articles across 188 different Wikipedias
column794: as of November 2021.[update][271][272] Cultural significance Main article: Wikipedia in culture Wikipedia Monument in Słubice
column796: by Mihran Hakobyan (2014) Wikipedia's content has also been used in academic studies
column799: and court cases.[W 121][273][274] The Parliament of Canada's website refers to Wikipedia's article on same-sex marriage in the "related links" section of its "further reading" list for the Civil Marriage Act.[275] The encyclopedia's assertions are increasingly used as a source by organizations such as the US federal courts and the World Intellectual Property Organization[276]—though mainly for supporting information rather than information decisive to a case.[277] Content appearing on Wikipedia has also been cited as a source and referenced in some US intelligence agency reports.[278] In December 2008
column800: the scientific journal RNA Biology launched a new section for descriptions of families of RNA molecules and requires authors who contribute to the section to also submit a draft article on the RNA family for publication in Wikipedia.[279] Wikipedia has also been used as a source in journalism
column802: and several reporters have been dismissed for plagiarizing from Wikipedia.[282][283][284][285] In 2006
column803: Time magazine recognized Wikipedia's participation (along with YouTube
column806: and Facebook) in the rapid growth of online collaboration and interaction by millions of people worldwide.[286] On September 16
column808: The Washington Post reported that Wikipedia had become a focal point in the 2008 US election campaign
column809: saying: "Type a candidate's name into Google
column810: and among the first results is a Wikipedia page
column811: making those entries arguably as important as any ad in defining a candidate. Already
column812: the presidential entries are being edited
column813: dissected and debated countless times each day."[287] An October 2007 Reuters article
column814: titled "Wikipedia page the latest status symbol"
column815: reported the recent phenomenon of how having a Wikipedia article vindicates one's notability.[288] One of the first times Wikipedia was involved in a governmental affair was on September 28
column817: when Italian politician Franco Grillini raised a parliamentary question with the minister of cultural resources and activities about the necessity of freedom of panorama. He said that the lack of such freedom forced Wikipedia
column819: to forbid all images of modern Italian buildings and art
column820: and claimed this was hugely damaging to tourist revenues.[289] Wikipedia
column821: an introduction – Erasmus Prize 2015 Jimmy Wales accepts the 2008 Quadriga A Mission of Enlightenment award on behalf of Wikipedia. A working group led by Peter Stone (formed as a part of the Stanford-based project One Hundred Year Study on Artificial Intelligence) in its report called Wikipedia "the best-known example of crowdsourcing ... that far exceeds traditionally-compiled information sources
column823: in scale and depth".[290][291] In a 2017 opinion piece for Wired
column824: Hossein Derakhshan describes Wikipedia as "one of the last remaining pillars of the open and decentralized web" and contrasted its existence as a text-based source of knowledge with social media and social networking services
column825: the latter having "since colonized the web for television's values". For Derakhshan
column826: Wikipedia's goal as an encyclopedia represents the Age of Enlightenment tradition of rationality triumphing over emotions
column827: a trend which he considers "endangered" due to the "gradual shift from a typographic culture to a photographic one
column828: which in turn mean[s] a shift from rationality to emotions
column829: exposition to entertainment". Rather than "sapere aude" (lit. 'dare to know')
column830: social networks have led to a culture of "dare not to care to know". This is while Wikipedia faces "a more concerning problem" than funding
column831: namely "a flattening growth rate in the number of contributors to the website". Consequently
column832: the challenge for Wikipedia and those who use it is to "save Wikipedia and its promise of a free and open collection of all human knowledge amid the conquest of new and old television—how to collect and preserve knowledge when nobody cares to know."[292] Awards Wikipedia team visiting the Parliament of Asturias Wikipedians meeting after the 2015 Asturias awards ceremony Wikipedia has won many awards
column833: receiving its first two major awards in May 2004.[W 122] The first was a Golden Nica for Digital Communities of the annual Prix Ars Electronica contest; this came with a €10
column836: 700) grant and an invitation to present at the PAE Cyberarts Festival in Austria later that year. The second was a Judges' Webby Award for the "community" category.[293] In 2007
column837: readers of brandchannel.com voted Wikipedia as the fourth-highest brand ranking
column838: receiving 15 percent of the votes in answer to the question "Which brand had the most impact on our lives in 2006?"[294] In September 2008
column839: Wikipedia received Quadriga A Mission of Enlightenment award of Werkstatt Deutschland along with Boris Tadić
column841: and Peter Gabriel. The award was presented to Wales by David Weinberger.[295] In 2015

column843: which recognizes exceptional contributions to culture
column845: [296] and the Spanish Princess of Asturias Award on International Cooperation.[297] Speaking at the Asturian Parliament in Oviedo

column847: Jimmy Wales praised the work of the Asturian Wikipedia users.[298] Satire See also: Category:Parodies of Wikipedia Comedian Stephen Colbert has parodied or referenced Wikipedia on numerous episodes of his show The Colbert Report and coined the related term wikiality

column850: [299] as well as the 2010 The Onion article "'L.A. Law' Wikipedia Page Viewed 874 Times Today".[300] In an April 2007 episode of the American television comedy The Office

column852: but this effort was prevented by other users on the article's talk page.[302] "My Number One Doctor"

column856: in which the fictitious Professor Wikipedia instructs a class with a medley of unverifiable and occasionally absurd statements.[304] The Dilbert comic strip from May 8

The Talk page concerned a fictional article describing the unintended consequences of the release of a plastic-eating fungus to clean up an oil spill. The article contained Talk page topics found on Wikipedia
column869: like discussions of changes in the articles priority level.[310] Sister projects – Wikimedia Main article: Wikimedia project Wikipedia has spawned several sister projects

column889: launched.[W 128] Publishing A group of Wikimedians of the Wikimedia DC chapter at the 2013 DC Wikimedia annual meeting standing in front of the Encyclopædia Britannica (back left) at the US National Archives The most obvious economic effect of Wikipedia has been the death of commercial encyclopedias
column890: especially printed versions like Encyclopædia Britannica
column891: which were unable to compete with a product that is essentially free.[314][315][316] Nicholas Carr's 2005 essay "The amorality of Web 2.0" criticizes websites with user-generated content (like Wikipedia) for possibly leading to professional (and
column893: superior) content producers' going out of business
column894: because "free trumps quality all the time". Carr wrote
column895: "Implicit in the ecstatic visions of Web 2.0 is the hegemony of the amateur. I for one can't imagine anything more frightening."[317] Others dispute the notion that Wikipedia
column897: will entirely displace traditional publications. Chris Anderson
column899: wrote in Nature that the "wisdom of crowds" approach of Wikipedia will not displace top scientific journals with rigorous peer review processes.[318] Wikipedia's influence on the biography publishing business has been a concern for some. Book publishing data tracker Nielsen BookScan stated in 2013 that biography sales were dropping "far more sharply".[319] Kathryn Hughes
column900: professor of life writing at the University of East Anglia and author of two biographies wrote
column902: if you can get all that information from Wikipedia
column903: what's left for biography?"[319] Research use Wikipedia has been widely used as a corpus for linguistic research in computational linguistics
column904: information retrieval and natural language processing.[320][321] In particular
column905: it commonly serves as a target knowledge base for the entity linking problem
column907: [322] and to the related problem of word-sense disambiguation.[323] Methods similar to wikification can in turn be used to find "missing" links in Wikipedia.[324] In 2015
column908: French researchers José Lages of the University of Franche-Comté in Besançon and Dima Shepelyansky of Paul Sabatier University in Toulouse published a global university ranking based on Wikipedia scholarly citations.[325][326][327] They used PageRank
column909: CheiRank and similar algorithms "followed by the number of appearances in the 24 different language editions of Wikipedia (descending order) and the century in which they were founded (ascending order)".[327][328] The study was updated in 2019.[329] In December 2015
column911: in a letter published in The Times newspaper
column912: that as a historian he resorted to Wikipedia "at least a dozen times a day"
column913: and had never yet caught it out. He described it as "a work of reference as useful as any in existence"
column914: with so wide a range that it is almost impossible to find a person
column916: or thing that it has left uncovered and that he could never have written his last two books without it.[330] A 2017 MIT study suggests that words used on Wikipedia articles end up in scientific publications.[331][332] Studies related to Wikipedia have been using machine learning and artificial intelligence[291] to support various operations. One of the most important areas is the automatic detection of vandalism[333][334] and data quality assessment in Wikipedia.[335][336] In February 2022
column917: civil servants from the UK's Housing
column918: Communities and Local Government Committee were found to have used Wikipedia for research after journalists at The Independent noted that parts of the document had been lifted directly from Wikipedia articles on Constantinople and the list of largest cities throughout history.[337] Related projects Several interactive multimedia encyclopedias incorporating entries written by the public existed long before Wikipedia was founded. The first of these was the 1986 BBC Domesday Project
column919: which included text (entered on BBC Micro computers) and photographs from more than a million contributors in the UK
column922: and culture of the UK. This was the first interactive multimedia encyclopedia (and was also the first major multimedia document connected through internal links)
column923: with the majority of articles being accessible through an interactive map of the UK. The user interface and part of the content of the Domesday Project were emulated on a website until 2008.[338] Several free-content
column924: collaborative encyclopedias were created around the same period as Wikipedia (e.g. Everything2)
column925: [339] with many later being merged into the project (e.g. GNE).[W 129] One of the most successful early online encyclopedias incorporating entries by the public was h2g2
column926: which was created by Douglas Adams in 1999. The h2g2 encyclopedia is relatively lighthearted
column927: focusing on articles which are both witty and informative.[340] Subsequent collaborative knowledge websites have drawn inspiration from Wikipedia. Others use more traditional peer review

column110: after graduating from RIT with a degree in film. He helps develop new talent by inviting RIT students to work on his production crews. Developing corn-based packaging is not only being used to counteract the amount of food waste going into landfills

Duffy created a degree program in the School of Individualized Study so she can one day establish a non-profit of her own. Education: A Powerful Tool for Sustainability Elizabeth Moore Sustainability Ph.D. Moore is researching nanomaterials and their use in clean energy technologies. She’s sharing this knowledge with future generations

The Hearing Test and Hearing Aid features are supported on AirPods Pro 2 with the latest firmware paired with a compatible iPhone or iPad with iOS 18 or iPadOS 18 and later and are intended for people 18 years old or older. The Hearing Aid feature is also supported on a compatible Mac with macOS Sequoia and later. It is intended for people with perceived mild to moderate hearing loss. Content: Skip to content Search for: Toggle Navigation Apply To SGU Request Information Categories Medical School Medical Practice Health Care Trends SGU Stories Caribbean Life Search for: – Medical School Blog 55 Top Medical Blogs Every Healthcare Pro Should Know 17 min read–Published On: June 7
column3: 2023–Categories: Health Care Trends– No matter how much you know about a particular medical field
column4: as a budding healthcare professional
column5: you always need to be thinking about what’s next. Thanks to advances in technology
column6: new clinical studies
column7: and ever-changing healthcare policy
column8: there’s always more to know. If you run an internet search for medical blogs
column9: you’ll come across hundreds of results. And figuring out which sources are reputable can take a lot of time. To help ease the process
column10: we compiled this list of 55 of our favorite medical blogs everyone in the field can learn from. Whether you’re considering medical school
column11: you’ve been a physician for years
column12: or you simply want to know how to make well-informed decisions about your own health
column13: there’s something on this list for everyone. Keep this list of medical blogs handy and the answers to your medical queries will always be just a few clicks away. Best general medical blogs If you’re interested in a wide range of medical topics
column14: these blogs are worth checking out. They’re also great for those who want to be more informed about health but have difficulty figuring out where to start. 1. Well Part of The New York Times
column15: Well is a great resource for everything from the latest research about a particular type of exercise to navigating relationships. Ask Well
column16: a column that taps physicians and other experts to answer common health questions
column17: is another highlight of the blog. 2. WebMD Doctors The well-known health website has quite a collection of blogs
column18: but WebMD Doctors stands out for how relatable it is. Each post is penned by a physician
column19: and the topics can be about parenting
column20: heart medication
column21: or how even health professionals struggle with healthy eating. 3. Cedars-Sinai Blog Plenty of medical institutions have blogs
column22: but Cedars-Sinai’s stands out for covering genuinely interesting topics. Instead of numerous posts about their faculty and facilities
column23: expect to read about health topics relevant to just about everyone. 4. Kaiser Health News If you find yourself constantly bookmarking health sections on news websites
column24: Kaiser Health News is a must-follow. Knowing where to start can be overwhelming with so many topics to choose from
column25: so using the KHN “Morning Briefing” is a nice way to see a snapshot of all the latest health happenings. 5. Harvard Health Blog This blog is part of Harvard Medical School’s family of publications and manages to answer questions most of us didn’t even think to ask. While topics are hard-hitting
column26: don’t expect to find anything terribly obscure when scrolling through these posts. 6. Everyday Health There’s a good chance Everyday Health is the most appropriately named blog on this list because it focuses on the health topics that consistently affect a wide range of people. They also get kudos for addressing the emotional challenges folks face when managing different conditions. 7. Shots This health blog from NPR takes a fairly broad look at the medical world
column27: so there’s something for everyone. In addition to the typical news
column28: there’s also some commentary about the intersection of health and pop culture
column29: plus the occasional feel-good piece. 8. Health Essentials Given that Cleveland Clinic is widely regarded as one of the best hospitals in the country
column30: it makes sense their Health Essentials blog is top-notch. There’s a good balance of practical health information
column31: safety tips
column32: and even healthy recipes. 9. To Your Health The Washington Post’s health blog takes a very news-focused approach
column34: diseases impacting the country and world
column35: and some stories with a bit of shock factor. It’s a great resource for following up on the stories that often get just 20 seconds of coverage during your favorite morning news broadcasts. Best blogs about medical technology Technology has transformed healthcare
column36: and not just in the way we maintain medical records. These blogs highlight how new devices
column37: techniques
column38: and security measures are improving the industry. 10. The Medical Futurist Don’t let the silly name fool you
column39: because The Medical Futurist is one of the best online resources for learning about technology in the medical sphere. There’s a real sense of skepticism in each post from medical doctor and geneticist Dr. Bertalan Mesko
column40: and the approach is refreshing. 11. Medgadget A lot of medical professionals have a colleague who always seems to know which new medical device stands a chance of seriously improving healthcare. It’s likely this colleague regularly peruses Medgadget
column41: a blog covering new technologies targeted toward numerous specialties. 12. 33 Charts All the new medical technology in the world isn’t very useful if physicians and other medical professionals can’t find a logical way to use it in their practices. The good news is 33 Charts
column42: a blog from pediatrician Dr. Bryan Vartabedian
column43: bridges the gap by offering insight about how physicians can embrace the digital world. 13. MassDevice For anything related to medical devices
column44: MassDevice is one of the most comprehensive resources available. While a lot of posts on the website will prove more useful for physicians and other healthcare professionals
column45: the blog itself is great for anyone who’s generally curious about how medical technology is changing the industry. 14. Health IT Buzz Health information technology might sound like a pretty specific topic
column46: but Health IT Buzz proves how much there is to consider. Transitioning to electronic health records has led to a lot of curiosity from physicians
column47: organizations
column49: so the blog’s commitment to answering questions in the comments section is especially appreciated. 15. ScienceDaily Medical Technology News This blog covers a whole host of topics
column50: so it’s not terribly surprising medical technology appears on the list. This particular section covers breaking news that has anything to do with medical technology
column51: whether it’s a new type of imaging to detect cancer or an up-and-coming surgical method. 16. Healthcare Innovation For anyone who’s found themselves both confused and frustrated when trying to do a little online research about health information technology
column52: the Healthcare Innovation blog will be a welcome read. The writers provide a lot of context and also offer their insight
column53: so readers walk away feeling educated. Best medical blogs about policy Policy plays an undeniably instrumental role in the type of care patients receive
column54: so this group of blogs will help you keep a pulse on any changes affecting the industry. 17. FDA Law Blog Because so much of what the FDA does involves food
column55: it’s easy to forget the organization also helps regulate drugs and medical devices. The law firm Hyman
column57: P.C. publishes FDA Law Blog to illustrate how regulations related to these topics play out both in the real world and in the courtroom. 18. USC-Brookings Schaeffer on Health Policy This blog from the Brookings Institution takes a look at how changes in health policy affect individuals as well as the broader system. You’ll also find information about healthcare policy around the globe. 19. HHS Blog The US Department of Health & Human Services works to improve public health
column58: and their blog highlights some of the ways that’s happening. Expect to read about emerging methods for treating and diagnosing diseases
column59: practical tips you can use to lead a healthier life
column60: and steps the government can take to improve health outcomes across the country. 20. Health Affairs Blog Most major news publications share what’s happening in health policy without going into much detail. This is where the Health Affairs Blog stands apart from the rest
column61: offering analysis on issues affecting healthcare. They also welcome submissions
column62: so feel free to chime in and pen a piece yourself. 21. eHealth POLITICO’s eHealth site covers everything happening
column64: in healthcare. The blog does a good job of reporting the latest happenings in Washington and also features insights from people who work in the healthcare industry. 22. Health Care Intelligence Anyone working in the healthcare field knows how quickly things can change
column65: so the weekly roundup from Health Care Intelligence is useful for getting a lot of information without having to spend hours reading. Each post shares the latest healthcare news from the last week
column66: then elaborates on the most important points. 23. Vital Signs The Vital Signs blog covers health policy news with a healthy dose of skepticism. This blog is able to discuss policy in a way that speaks to individuals and political parties
column67: as well as people in the healthcare industry
column68: without coming across as either too cheerful or too dismal. 24. CHIRblog This blog from the Georgetown University Health Policy Institute covers all things health insurance. Through expert posts
column69: the blog aims to “untangle the often arcane world of insurance regulation.” This means answering questions about federal and state rules
column70: and clarifying what they mean for individuals and their families. Best blogs about medical school Prospective and current med students have tons of questions about their chosen field of study
column71: so these blogs are a great place to learn about the interview process
column72: what it’s like to be part of a white coat ceremony
column73: and how they can prepare for residency. 25. Med School Insight The folks at Kaplan have put together Med School Insight as a way to help current medical students work their way through education
column75: and beyond. Stories answer real-life questions like “How do I know what specialty to choose?” and “Is it feasible to own a pet while going through medical school?” 26. The MedEdits Post This online resource is helpful for current medical students
column76: but it might be even better for those who have yet to apply. There’s lots of information about what undergrads can do to set themselves up for the future and tips on how to prepare for medical school interviews. The blog also shares advice for writing application essays and the actual secondary prompts medical schools have used in the past. 27. Life of a Med Student Though Life of a Med Student was started by one student as a Twitter account
column77: it has since evolved into a full-fledged website with numerous guest contributors. Expect to find plenty of amusing stories to peruse during a lunch break
column78: as well as advice from people who have been there. 28. Medical School Admissions Accepted’s blog for medical students is a good place to start when looking for answers to big questions about applying to and interviewing for medical school. There are pointers for how to start writing application essays
column79: guides for how prospective students should dress for interviews
column80: and tips for those gearing up for residency. The associated podcast’s interviews with physicians are an added bonus. 29. Medical School Admissions Doctor U.S. News & World Report’s medical student–focused blog features plenty of physician voices
column81: but it also lets current students share their insights. Most of the pieces are quick reads and give prospective students practical advice they can start using right away. 30. Merck Manuals Student Stories No one knows more about medical school than past and current students. Merck Manuals Student Stories covers all the major milestones
column82: but the blog also offers a lot of practical advice for managing stress and sticking to a healthy lifestyle. 31. BoardVitals Blog While the BoardVitals blog is jam-packed with information geared toward all types of healthcare workers and medical specialties
column83: the student-facing content really stands out. There are loads of posts specifically about medical licensing exams
column84: including the series designed for osteopathic students. The tips for combatting stress and managing the specific difficulties doctors face are also helpful. 32. St. George’s University School of Medicine Blog We’d be remiss not to include this blog in the list. Nestled on the idyllic island of Grenada
column85: St. George’s University (SGU) has been the largest provider of doctors into first-year US residencies for nine years running.* In addition to training high-quality physicians
column86: SGU provides pre-med students with a multitude of information about medical school
column89: and more in the School of Medicine Blog. Best special interest medical blogs Maybe a family member has a particular disease
column90: or perhaps you’re interested in pursuing a career in sports medicine. Look to these blogs for a deeper dive into the specific topics that interest you. 33. Childhood Obesity News Based on a book by pediatrician and childhood obesity expert Dr. Robert Pretlow
column91: this blog covers everything from food addiction to public policy designed to curb weight gain. The insights shared on Childhood Obesity News can benefit parents
column92: but also pediatricians and other doctors who work with children. 34. Dr. Barnard’s Blog Most people have heard someone refer to food as medicine
column93: but it’s not usually very clear what they mean. Dr. Neal Barnard is the exception because
column94: as a physician who specializes in nutrition and preventive medicine
column95: he’s able to clearly explain the role food plays in disease prevention. In addition to written stories
column96: Dr. Barnard’s Blog also uses infographics and other visuals to present information in a concise way. 35. Neurosurgery Blog At the top of the page

column105: and policy commentary related to geriatrics and palliative care. These stories can be useful for physicians and others working in the healthcare industry

column108: try following these blogs to make sure you never miss a thing. 40. The JAMA Network Home of the Journal of the American Medical Association and a number of other publications

column110: this resource is best for those already comfortable with scientific language. 41. Howard Hughes Medical Institute News The Howard Hughes Medical Institute supports research efforts in cell biology
column114: and structural biology. Published studies are highlighted on the news blog and presented in a way that’s easy to digest. 42. On Medicine BioMed Central publishes a number of blogs

column116: this blog also delves into quality control issues that sometimes occur in medical research and points out important ethical considerations. 43. column117: such as using music in a treatment plan. column118: so there’s a lot to read. The options to sort headlines by recency or popularity are nice for those who don’t know exactly where to start. 45. column120: and other healthcare workers likely want to read articles a little more tailored to their needs. These medical blogs offer relevant information and can help provide a support network. 46. Global Health Justice and Governance This organization’s blog discusses ways to invest in global health and points out potential roadblocks. The Collective Voice Not everyone understands how global health concerns affect them as an individual
column134: but The Collective Voice helps put things in perspective. Many posts discuss how health concerns in certain countries can have serious implications for people elsewhere. 54. Global Health Policy Blog While it’s easy to think about how health policies affect an individual country

column140: based on internal SGU graduate/expected graduate and residency placement data as of March 2023. 55 Top Medical Blogs Every Healthcare Pro Should Know No matter how much you know about a particular medical field
column142: you always need to be thinking about what’s next. Thanks to advances in technology
column145: there’s always more to know. If you run an internet search for medical blogs
column146: you’ll come across hundreds of results. And figuring out which sources are reputable can take a lot of time. To help ease the process
column147: we compiled this list of 55 of our favorite medical blogs everyone in the field can learn from. Whether you’re considering medical school
column148: you’ve been a physician for years
column149: or you simply want to know how to make well-informed decisions about your own health
column150: there’s something on this list for everyone. Keep this list of medical blogs handy and the answers to your medical queries will always be just a few clicks away. Best general medical blogs If you’re interested in a wide range of medical topics
column151: these blogs are worth checking out. They’re also great for those who want to be more informed about health but have difficulty figuring out where to start. 1. Well Part of The New York Times
column152: Well is a great resource for everything from the latest research about a particular type of exercise to navigating relationships. Ask Well
column153: a column that taps physicians and other experts to answer common health questions
column154: is another highlight of the blog. 2. WebMD Doctors The well-known health website has quite a collection of blogs
column155: but WebMD Doctors stands out for how relatable it is. Each post is penned by a physician
column156: and the topics can be about parenting
column158: or how even health professionals struggle with healthy eating. 3. Cedars-Sinai Blog Plenty of medical institutions have blogs
column159: but Cedars-Sinai’s stands out for covering genuinely interesting topics. Instead of numerous posts about their faculty and facilities
column160: expect to read about health topics relevant to just about everyone. 4. Kaiser Health News If you find yourself constantly bookmarking health sections on news websites
column161: Kaiser Health News is a must-follow. Knowing where to start can be overwhelming with so many topics to choose from
column162: so using the KHN “Morning Briefing” is a nice way to see a snapshot of all the latest health happenings. 5. Harvard Health Blog This blog is part of Harvard Medical School’s family of publications and manages to answer questions most of us didn’t even think to ask. While topics are hard-hitting
column163: don’t expect to find anything terribly obscure when scrolling through these posts. 6. Everyday Health There’s a good chance Everyday Health is the most appropriately named blog on this list because it focuses on the health topics that consistently affect a wide range of people. They also get kudos for addressing the emotional challenges folks face when managing different conditions. 7. Shots This health blog from NPR takes a fairly broad look at the medical world
column164: so there’s something for everyone. In addition to the typical news
column165: there’s also some commentary about the intersection of health and pop culture
column166: plus the occasional feel-good piece. 8. Health Essentials Given that Cleveland Clinic is widely regarded as one of the best hospitals in the country
column167: it makes sense their Health Essentials blog is top-notch. There’s a good balance of practical health information
column169: and even healthy recipes. 9. To Your Health The Washington Post’s health blog takes a very news-focused approach
column171: diseases impacting the country and world
column172: and some stories with a bit of shock factor. It’s a great resource for following up on the stories that often get just 20 seconds of coverage during your favorite morning news broadcasts. Best blogs about medical technology Technology has transformed healthcare
column173: and not just in the way we maintain medical records. These blogs highlight how new devices
column175: and security measures are improving the industry. 10. The Medical Futurist Don’t let the silly name fool you
column176: because The Medical Futurist is one of the best online resources for learning about technology in the medical sphere. There’s a real sense of skepticism in each post from medical doctor and geneticist Dr. Bertalan Mesko
column177: and the approach is refreshing. 11. Medgadget A lot of medical professionals have a colleague who always seems to know which new medical device stands a chance of seriously improving healthcare. It’s likely this colleague regularly peruses Medgadget
column178: a blog covering new technologies targeted toward numerous specialties. 12. 33 Charts All the new medical technology in the world isn’t very useful if physicians and other medical professionals can’t find a logical way to use it in their practices. The good news is 33 Charts
column179: a blog from pediatrician Dr. Bryan Vartabedian
column180: bridges the gap by offering insight about how physicians can embrace the digital world. 13. MassDevice For anything related to medical devices
column181: MassDevice is one of the most comprehensive resources available. While a lot of posts on the website will prove more useful for physicians and other healthcare professionals
column182: the blog itself is great for anyone who’s generally curious about how medical technology is changing the industry. 14. Health IT Buzz Health information technology might sound like a pretty specific topic
column183: but Health IT Buzz proves how much there is to consider. Transitioning to electronic health records has led to a lot of curiosity from physicians
column186: so the blog’s commitment to answering questions in the comments section is especially appreciated. 15. ScienceDaily Medical Technology News This blog covers a whole host of topics
column187: so it’s not terribly surprising medical technology appears on the list. This particular section covers breaking news that has anything to do with medical technology
column188: whether it’s a new type of imaging to detect cancer or an up-and-coming surgical method. 16. Healthcare Innovation For anyone who’s found themselves both confused and frustrated when trying to do a little online research about health information technology
column189: the Healthcare Innovation blog will be a welcome read. The writers provide a lot of context and also offer their insight
column190: so readers walk away feeling educated. Best medical blogs about policy Policy plays an undeniably instrumental role in the type of care patients receive
column191: so this group of blogs will help you keep a pulse on any changes affecting the industry. 17. FDA Law Blog Because so much of what the FDA does involves food
column192: it’s easy to forget the organization also helps regulate drugs and medical devices. The law firm Hyman
column194: P.C. publishes FDA Law Blog to illustrate how regulations related to these topics play out both in the real world and in the courtroom. 18. USC-Brookings Schaeffer on Health Policy This blog from the Brookings Institution takes a look at how changes in health policy affect individuals as well as the broader system. You’ll also find information about healthcare policy around the globe. 19. HHS Blog The US Department of Health & Human Services works to improve public health
column195: and their blog highlights some of the ways that’s happening. Expect to read about emerging methods for treating and diagnosing diseases
column196: practical tips you can use to lead a healthier life
column197: and steps the government can take to improve health outcomes across the country. 20. Health Affairs Blog Most major news publications share what’s happening in health policy without going into much detail. This is where the Health Affairs Blog stands apart from the rest
column198: offering analysis on issues affecting healthcare. They also welcome submissions
column199: so feel free to chime in and pen a piece yourself. 21. eHealth POLITICO’s eHealth site covers everything happening
column201: in healthcare. The blog does a good job of reporting the latest happenings in Washington and also features insights from people who work in the healthcare industry. 22. Health Care Intelligence Anyone working in the healthcare field knows how quickly things can change

column204: as well as people in the healthcare industry
column205: without coming across as either too cheerful or too dismal. 24. CHIRblog This blog from the Georgetown University Health Policy Institute covers all things health insurance. Through expert posts

column207: and clarifying what they mean for individuals and their families. Best blogs about medical school Prospective and current med students have tons of questions about their chosen field of study

column213: but it might be even better for those who have yet to apply. column5: Morocco. On Wikipedia
column6: trusted users may be appointed as administrators (also referred to as admins
column7: sysops or janitors)
column8: [1]: 327  following a successful request for adminship. Currently
column9: there are 847 administrators on the English Wikipedia.[2] Administrators have additional technical privileges compared with other editors
column10: such as being able to protect and delete pages and being able to block users from editing pages. On Wikipedia
column11: becoming an administrator is often referred to as "being given [or taking up] the mop"
column12: [3] a term which has also been used elsewhere.[4] In 2006
column13: The New York Times reported that administrators on Wikipedia
column14: of whom there were then about 1
column16: were "geographically diverse".[5] In July 2012
column17: it was widely reported that Wikipedia was "running out of administrators"
column18: because in 2005 and 2006
column19: 40 to 50 people were often appointed administrators each month
column20: but in the first half of 2012
column21: only nine in total were appointed.[6][7] However
column22: Jimmy Wales
column23: Wikipedia's co-founder
column24: denied that this was a crisis or that Wikipedia was running out of admins
column26: "The number of admins has been stable for about two years
column27: there's really nothing going on."[8] Wales had previously (in a message sent to the English Wikipedia mailing list on February 11
column28: 2003) stated that being an admin is "not a big deal"
column29: and that "It's merely a technical matter that the powers given to sysops are not given out to everyone."[9] In his 2008 book Wikipedia: The Missing Manual
column30: John Broughton states that while many people think of administrators on Wikipedia as judges
column31: that is not the purpose of the role.[10] Instead
column32: he says
column33: admins usually "delete pages" and "protect pages involved in edit wars".[10] Wikipedia administrators are not employees or agents of the Wikimedia Foundation.[11] Requests for adminship[edit] While the first Wikipedia administrators were appointed by Jimmy Wales in October 2001
column34: [12] administrator privileges on Wikipedia are now granted through a process known as requests for adminship (RfA).[1] Any registered editor may nominate themselves
column35: or may request another editor to do so. The process has been said to be "akin to putting someone through the Supreme Court" by Andrew Lih
column36: a scientist and professor who is himself an administrator on the English Wikipedia. Lih also said
column37: "It's pretty much a hazing ritual at this point"
column38: in contrast to how the process worked early in Wikipedia's history
column39: when all one had to do to become an admin was "prove you weren't a bozo".[6] Candidacy for the role is normally considered only after "extensive work on the wiki".[1] While any editor may vote in an RfA
column40: the outcome is not determined by a majority vote
column41: but rather by whether consensus has been reached that the candidate would make a good administrator
column42: a decision that can only be made by a bureaucrat
column43: a Wikipedia editor who is also appointed by the community through a "request" process
column44: though the process is much stricter for them than for administrators.[13] This may have been implemented as a result of RfAs attracting increasing levels of attention: Stvilia et al. quoted that "Prior to mid-2005
column45: RfAs typically did not attract much attention. Since then
column46: it has become quite common for RfAs to attract huge numbers of RfA groupies who all support one another"
column47: [14] with the record number of votes in one RfA as of May 2022 being 468 for the RfA of longtime editor Tamzin Hadasa Kelly
column48: which was supported by 340 users and opposed by 116 amidst controversy over their criticism of supporters of Donald Trump.[15] Role[edit] Once granted administrator privileges
column49: a user has access to additional functions in order to perform certain duties.[6] These include "messy cleanup work"
column51: protecting pages (restricting editing privileges to that page)
column52: [16]: 66  and blocking the accounts of disruptive users.[1][6] Blocking a user must be done according to Wikipedia's policies and a reason must be stated for the block
column53: which will be permanently logged by the software.[1]: 401 [16]: 120  Use of this privilege to "gain editing advantages" is considered inappropriate.[1] Scientific studies[edit] A 2013 scientific paper by researchers from Virginia Tech and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute found that after editors are promoted to administrator status
column54: they often focus more on articles about controversial topics than they did before. The researchers also proposed an alternative method for choosing administrators
column55: in which more weight is given to the votes of experienced editors.[17] This corresponds to a modality of plural voting. Another paper
column56: presented at the 2008 Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
column58: 551 requests for adminship from January 2006 to October 2007
column59: with the goal of determining which (if any) of the criteria recommended in Wikipedia's Guide to requests for adminship[18] were the best predictors of whether the user in question would actually become an admin.[4] In December 2013
column60: a similar study was published by researchers from the Polish-Japanese Institute of Information Technology in Warsaw
column61: which aimed to model the results of requests for adminship on the Polish Wikipedia using a model derived from Wikipedia's edit history. They found that they could "classify the votes in the RfA procedures using this model with an accuracy level that should be sufficient to recommend candidates."[19] References[edit] ^ a b c d e f g Ayers
