column760: scoring over four of a possible five in a poll of approximately 200
column761: 000 users downloading from Google.[W 114][W 115] The version for iOS was released on April 3
column763: to similar reviews.[W 116] Wikipedia Zero was an initiative of the Wikimedia Foundation to expand the reach of the encyclopedia to the developing countries by partnering with mobile operators to allow free access.[W 117][254] It was discontinued in February 2018 due to lack of participation from mobile operators.[W 117] Andrew Lih and Andrew Brown both maintain editing Wikipedia with smartphones is difficult and this discourages new potential contributors.[255][256] Lih states that the number of Wikipedia editors has been declining after several years
column764: [255] and Tom Simonite of MIT Technology Review claims the bureaucratic structure and rules are a factor in this. Simonite alleges some Wikipedians use the labyrinthine rules and guidelines to dominate others and those editors have a vested interest in keeping the status quo.[38] Lih alleges there is a serious disagreement among existing contributors on how to resolve this. Lih fears for Wikipedia's long-term future while Brown fears problems with Wikipedia will remain and rival encyclopedias will not replace it.[255][256] Chinese access Access to Wikipedia has been blocked in mainland China since May 2015.[16][257][258] This was done after Wikipedia started to use HTTPS encryption
column765: which made selective censorship more difficult.[259] Cultural influence Trusted source to combat fake news In 2017–18
column766: after a barrage of false news reports
column767: both Facebook and YouTube announced they would rely on Wikipedia to help their users evaluate reports and reject false news.[13][14] Noam Cohen
column768: writing in The Washington Post states
column769: "YouTube's reliance on Wikipedia to set the record straight builds on the thinking of another fact-challenged platform
column771: which announced last year that Wikipedia would help its users root out 'fake news'."[14][260] Readership In February 2014
column772: The New York Times reported that Wikipedia was ranked fifth globally among all websites
column773: stating "With 18 billion page views and nearly 500 million unique visitors a month
column777: the largest with 1.2 billion unique visitors."[45] However
column778: its ranking dropped to 13th globally by June 2020 due mostly to a rise in popularity of Chinese websites for online shopping.[261] The website has since recovered its ranking as of April 2022.[262] In addition to logistic growth in the number of its articles
column779: [W 118] Wikipedia has steadily gained status as a general reference website since its inception in 2001.[263] The number of readers of Wikipedia worldwide reached 365 million at the end of 2009.[W 119] The Pew Internet and American Life project found that one third of US Internet users consulted Wikipedia.[264] In 2011
column780: Business Insider gave Wikipedia a valuation of $4 billion if it ran advertisements.[265] According to "Wikipedia Readership Survey 2011"
column781: the average age of Wikipedia readers is 36
column782: with a rough parity between genders. Almost half of Wikipedia readers visit the site more than five times a month
column783: and a similar number of readers specifically look for Wikipedia in search engine results. About 47 percent of Wikipedia readers do not realize that Wikipedia is a non-profit organization.[W 120] As of February 2023
column784: [update] Wikipedia attracts around 2 billion unique devices monthly
column785: with the English Wikipedia receiving 10 billion pageviews each month.[W 1] COVID-19 pandemic Main article: Wikipedia coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic During the COVID-19 pandemic
column786: Wikipedia's coverage of the pandemic and fight against misinformation received international media attention
column787: and brought an increase in Wikipedia readership overall.[266][267][268][269] Noam Cohen wrote in Wired that Wikipedia's effort to combat misinformation related to the pandemic was different from other major websites
column790: Facebook and the others can learn to address misinformation more effectively
column791: Wikipedia will remain the last best place on the Internet."[267] In October 2020
column792: the World Health Organization announced they were freely licensing its infographics and other materials on Wikimedia projects.[270] There were nearly 7
column793: 000 COVID-19 related Wikipedia articles across 188 different Wikipedias
column794: as of November 2021.[update][271][272] Cultural significance Main article: Wikipedia in culture Wikipedia Monument in Słubice
column796: by Mihran Hakobyan (2014) Wikipedia's content has also been used in academic studies
column799: and court cases.[W 121][273][274] The Parliament of Canada's website refers to Wikipedia's article on same-sex marriage in the "related links" section of its "further reading" list for the Civil Marriage Act.[275] The encyclopedia's assertions are increasingly used as a source by organizations such as the US federal courts and the World Intellectual Property Organization[276]—though mainly for supporting information rather than information decisive to a case.[277] Content appearing on Wikipedia has also been cited as a source and referenced in some US intelligence agency reports.[278] In December 2008
column800: the scientific journal RNA Biology launched a new section for descriptions of families of RNA molecules and requires authors who contribute to the section to also submit a draft article on the RNA family for publication in Wikipedia.[279] Wikipedia has also been used as a source in journalism
column802: and several reporters have been dismissed for plagiarizing from Wikipedia.[282][283][284][285] In 2006
column803: Time magazine recognized Wikipedia's participation (along with YouTube
column806: and Facebook) in the rapid growth of online collaboration and interaction by millions of people worldwide.[286] On September 16
column808: The Washington Post reported that Wikipedia had become a focal point in the 2008 US election campaign
column809: saying: "Type a candidate's name into Google
column810: and among the first results is a Wikipedia page
column811: making those entries arguably as important as any ad in defining a candidate. Already
column812: the presidential entries are being edited
column813: dissected and debated countless times each day."[287] An October 2007 Reuters article
column814: titled "Wikipedia page the latest status symbol"
column815: reported the recent phenomenon of how having a Wikipedia article vindicates one's notability.[288] One of the first times Wikipedia was involved in a governmental affair was on September 28
column817: when Italian politician Franco Grillini raised a parliamentary question with the minister of cultural resources and activities about the necessity of freedom of panorama. He said that the lack of such freedom forced Wikipedia
column819: to forbid all images of modern Italian buildings and art
column820: and claimed this was hugely damaging to tourist revenues.[289] Wikipedia
column821: an introduction – Erasmus Prize 2015 Jimmy Wales accepts the 2008 Quadriga A Mission of Enlightenment award on behalf of Wikipedia. A working group led by Peter Stone (formed as a part of the Stanford-based project One Hundred Year Study on Artificial Intelligence) in its report called Wikipedia "the best-known example of crowdsourcing ... that far exceeds traditionally-compiled information sources
column823: in scale and depth".[290][291] In a 2017 opinion piece for Wired
column824: Hossein Derakhshan describes Wikipedia as "one of the last remaining pillars of the open and decentralized web" and contrasted its existence as a text-based source of knowledge with social media and social networking services
column825: the latter having "since colonized the web for television's values". For Derakhshan
column826: Wikipedia's goal as an encyclopedia represents the Age of Enlightenment tradition of rationality triumphing over emotions
column827: a trend which he considers "endangered" due to the "gradual shift from a typographic culture to a photographic one
column828: which in turn mean[s] a shift from rationality to emotions
column829: exposition to entertainment". Rather than "sapere aude" (lit. 'dare to know')
column830: social networks have led to a culture of "dare not to care to know". This is while Wikipedia faces "a more concerning problem" than funding
column831: namely "a flattening growth rate in the number of contributors to the website". Consequently
column832: the challenge for Wikipedia and those who use it is to "save Wikipedia and its promise of a free and open collection of all human knowledge amid the conquest of new and old television—how to collect and preserve knowledge when nobody cares to know."[292] Awards Wikipedia team visiting the Parliament of Asturias Wikipedians meeting after the 2015 Asturias awards ceremony Wikipedia has won many awards
column833: receiving its first two major awards in May 2004.[W 122] The first was a Golden Nica for Digital Communities of the annual Prix Ars Electronica contest; this came with a €10
column836: 700) grant and an invitation to present at the PAE Cyberarts Festival in Austria later that year. The second was a Judges' Webby Award for the "community" category.[293] In 2007
column837: readers of brandchannel.com voted Wikipedia as the fourth-highest brand ranking
column838: receiving 15 percent of the votes in answer to the question "Which brand had the most impact on our lives in 2006?"[294] In September 2008
column839: Wikipedia received Quadriga A Mission of Enlightenment award of Werkstatt Deutschland along with Boris Tadić
column841: and Peter Gabriel. The award was presented to Wales by David Weinberger.[295] In 2015
column842: Wikipedia was awarded both the annual Erasmus Prize
column843: which recognizes exceptional contributions to culture
column845: [296] and the Spanish Princess of Asturias Award on International Cooperation.[297] Speaking at the Asturian Parliament in Oviedo
column846: the city that hosts the awards ceremony
column847: Jimmy Wales praised the work of the Asturian Wikipedia users.[298] Satire See also: Category:Parodies of Wikipedia Comedian Stephen Colbert has parodied or referenced Wikipedia on numerous episodes of his show The Colbert Report and coined the related term wikiality
column848: meaning "together we can create a reality that we all agree on—the reality we just agreed on".[167] Another example can be found in "Wikipedia Celebrates 750 Years of American Independence"
column849: a July 2006 front-page article in The Onion
column850: [299] as well as the 2010 The Onion article "'L.A. Law' Wikipedia Page Viewed 874 Times Today".[300] In an April 2007 episode of the American television comedy The Office
column851: office manager (Michael Scott) is shown relying on a hypothetical Wikipedia article for information on negotiation tactics to assist him in negotiating lesser pay for an employee.[301] Viewers of the show tried to add the episode's mention of the page as a section of the actual Wikipedia article on negotiation
column852: but this effort was prevented by other users on the article's talk page.[302] "My Number One Doctor"
column853: a 2007 episode of the television show Scrubs
column854: played on the perception that Wikipedia is an unreliable reference tool with a scene in which Perry Cox reacts to a patient who says that a Wikipedia article indicates that the raw food diet reverses the effects of bone cancer by retorting that the same editor who wrote that article also wrote the Battlestar Galactica episode guide.[303] In 2008
column855: the comedy website CollegeHumor produced a video sketch named "Professor Wikipedia"
column856: in which the fictitious Professor Wikipedia instructs a class with a medley of unverifiable and occasionally absurd statements.[304] The Dilbert comic strip from May 8
column858: features a character supporting an improbable claim by saying "Give me ten minutes and then check Wikipedia."[305] In July 2009
column859: BBC Radio 4 broadcast a comedy series called Bigipedia
column860: which was set on a website which was a parody of Wikipedia.[306] Some of the sketches were directly inspired by Wikipedia and its articles.[307] On August 23
column862: the New Yorker website published a cartoon with this caption: "Dammit
column864: have you considered the pronoun war that this is going to start on your Wikipedia page?"[308] The cartoon referred to Chelsea Elizabeth Manning (born Bradley Edward Manning)
column867: and former United States Army soldier who had recently come out as a trans woman.[309] In June 2024
column868: nature.com published a fictional Wikipedia Talk page under the title "Plastic-eating fungus caused doomsday" by Emma Burnett. The Talk page concerned a fictional article describing the unintended consequences of the release of a plastic-eating fungus to clean up an oil spill. The article contained Talk page topics found on Wikipedia
column869: like discussions of changes in the articles priority level.[310] Sister projects – Wikimedia Main article: Wikimedia project Wikipedia has spawned several sister projects
column870: which are also wikis run by the Wikimedia Foundation. These other Wikimedia projects include Wiktionary
column871: a dictionary project launched in December 2002
column873: a collection of quotations created a week after Wikimedia launched
column875: a collection of collaboratively written free textbooks and annotated texts
column877: a site devoted to free-knowledge multimedia
column881: a project for the creation of free learning materials and the provision of online learning activities.[W 127] Another sister project of Wikipedia
column883: is a catalog of all species
column884: but is not open for public editing.[312] In 2012
column889: launched.[W 128] Publishing A group of Wikimedians of the Wikimedia DC chapter at the 2013 DC Wikimedia annual meeting standing in front of the Encyclopædia Britannica (back left) at the US National Archives The most obvious economic effect of Wikipedia has been the death of commercial encyclopedias
column890: especially printed versions like Encyclopædia Britannica
column891: which were unable to compete with a product that is essentially free.[314][315][316] Nicholas Carr's 2005 essay "The amorality of Web 2.0" criticizes websites with user-generated content (like Wikipedia) for possibly leading to professional (and
column893: superior) content producers' going out of business
column894: because "free trumps quality all the time". Carr wrote
column895: "Implicit in the ecstatic visions of Web 2.0 is the hegemony of the amateur. I for one can't imagine anything more frightening."[317] Others dispute the notion that Wikipedia
column897: will entirely displace traditional publications. Chris Anderson
column899: wrote in Nature that the "wisdom of crowds" approach of Wikipedia will not displace top scientific journals with rigorous peer review processes.[318] Wikipedia's influence on the biography publishing business has been a concern for some. Book publishing data tracker Nielsen BookScan stated in 2013 that biography sales were dropping "far more sharply".[319] Kathryn Hughes
column900: professor of life writing at the University of East Anglia and author of two biographies wrote
column902: if you can get all that information from Wikipedia
column903: what's left for biography?"[319] Research use Wikipedia has been widely used as a corpus for linguistic research in computational linguistics
column904: information retrieval and natural language processing.[320][321] In particular
column905: it commonly serves as a target knowledge base for the entity linking problem
column907: [322] and to the related problem of word-sense disambiguation.[323] Methods similar to wikification can in turn be used to find "missing" links in Wikipedia.[324] In 2015
column908: French researchers José Lages of the University of Franche-Comté in Besançon and Dima Shepelyansky of Paul Sabatier University in Toulouse published a global university ranking based on Wikipedia scholarly citations.[325][326][327] They used PageRank
column909: CheiRank and similar algorithms "followed by the number of appearances in the 24 different language editions of Wikipedia (descending order) and the century in which they were founded (ascending order)".[327][328] The study was updated in 2019.[329] In December 2015
column911: in a letter published in The Times newspaper
column912: that as a historian he resorted to Wikipedia "at least a dozen times a day"
column913: and had never yet caught it out. He described it as "a work of reference as useful as any in existence"
column914: with so wide a range that it is almost impossible to find a person
column916: or thing that it has left uncovered and that he could never have written his last two books without it.[330] A 2017 MIT study suggests that words used on Wikipedia articles end up in scientific publications.[331][332] Studies related to Wikipedia have been using machine learning and artificial intelligence[291] to support various operations. One of the most important areas is the automatic detection of vandalism[333][334] and data quality assessment in Wikipedia.[335][336] In February 2022
column917: civil servants from the UK's Housing
column918: Communities and Local Government Committee were found to have used Wikipedia for research after journalists at The Independent noted that parts of the document had been lifted directly from Wikipedia articles on Constantinople and the list of largest cities throughout history.[337] Related projects Several interactive multimedia encyclopedias incorporating entries written by the public existed long before Wikipedia was founded. The first of these was the 1986 BBC Domesday Project
column919: which included text (entered on BBC Micro computers) and photographs from more than a million contributors in the UK
column922: and culture of the UK. This was the first interactive multimedia encyclopedia (and was also the first major multimedia document connected through internal links)
column923: with the majority of articles being accessible through an interactive map of the UK. The user interface and part of the content of the Domesday Project were emulated on a website until 2008.[338] Several free-content
column924: collaborative encyclopedias were created around the same period as Wikipedia (e.g. Everything2)
column925: [339] with many later being merged into the project (e.g. GNE).[W 129] One of the most successful early online encyclopedias incorporating entries by the public was h2g2
column926: which was created by Douglas Adams in 1999. The h2g2 encyclopedia is relatively lighthearted
column927: focusing on articles which are both witty and informative.[340] Subsequent collaborative knowledge websites have drawn inspiration from Wikipedia. Others use more traditional peer review
column928: such as Encyclopedia of Life and the online wiki encyclopedias Scholarpedia and Citizendium.[341][342] The latter was started by Sanger in an attempt to create a reliable alternative to Wikipedia.[343][344] See also Main category: Wikipedia Internet portal Wikipedia portal Democratization of knowledge Interpedia – an early proposal for a collaborative Internet encyclopedia List of films about Wikipedia List of online encyclopedias List of Wikipedia controversies List of wikis Network effect Outline of Wikipedia – guide to the subject of Wikipedia presented as a tree structured list of its subtopics; for an outline of the contents of Wikipedia

column19: helpful reviews. Rated 5 out of 5 stars IPhone 16 Pro Max Review Incentivized Verified Purchaser Owned for 3 weeks My Best Buy® Member I preordered the iPhone 16 pro max to pick it up in September on the day it released. Previously
column20: I had an iPhone 12 pro. So my phone was about 4 years old plus I had broken it( yikes). Now that I’ve had it for about a month
column21: I can say it was so worth the purchase. I love how big it is
column22: the color
column23: and the chrome look on the sides of the phone. Camera wise
column24: AMAZING. My 12 pro had 3 cameras but apple went all out with the 16 camera. I have mine set at 4k and they’re the best photos. The phone is super quick
column26: and has more cool features to it. The side camera button and action button on the top left i was most excited about. It’s super convenient when you take photos. As far as the action button
column27: mine is set to turning the ringer on and off. I found it annoying to move my old ringer button left or right. To add
column28: the brightness and sound are quality. It could just be new phone speakers
column29: but it’s quite loud
column30: in a good way. If you’re looking for a new phone or upgrade
column31: this is it.Read More This review is from Apple - iPhone 16 Pro Max 256GB - Apple Intelligence - White Titanium (Verizon) Posted 3 weeks ago by tessengell Rated 5 out of 5 stars The Best Incentivized Verified Purchaser Owned for 3 weeks My Best Buy® Member Very easy transaction and o always get my phones from Best BuyRead More This review is from Apple - iPhone 16 Pro Max 256GB - Apple Intelligence - Black Titanium (Verizon) Posted 1 week ago by AnthonyM Rated 4 out of 5 stars Its a decent iPhone but should be better Incentivized Verified Purchaser Owned for less than 1 week My Best Buy® Member I give it 4 stars depending on what you are upgrading from. If from something older than a 13 or so then it will be a pretty amazing upgrade. But there are still a few dated things about this phone that make me give 1 star less. I feel like Apple is a bit behind the curve at this point. This phone is still pretty amazing but it could be better. Design: Meh I mean there is only so much you can do with an iPhone or any phone but this is dated. I can't stand the camera bump and how it makes the phone tilt. If you use your phone careless it's a huge pain. The titanium is OK
column32: but honestly the thing is far too heavy. And it got a smidge heavier from the 15 Pro Max
column33: these phones need to lose some weight to be truly comfortable. Screen: Exceptional. the 120MHz and colors
column34: etc are all great. Apple needs to work on PWM (flickering) if you are sensitive to it (many are not) its not great
column35: Apple could spring a few bucks to have a great MHz but they have not done so and its cheap in my opinion. But overall it's a great display. The 16 Plus should have 120MHz at this point I would have gotten that one if it did. Again Apple being cheap and not bringing tech that should be in 2024 as a minimum on all devices given what they charge. A18 Pro: amazing I mean iOS will not even blink with this chip. The phone can overheat but so far it's been good compared to my 15Max which was overheating constantly and while annoying would constantly dim the display and that was super annoying when it happened. So let's hope that is truly taken care of. Colors: So boring. I got the Desert and its nice
column36: its like a Rosy Gold in certain lighting think iPhone 12 or XS. It's not ugly but the colors are just so bland compared to the 16. And it's a shame that Apple cannot seem to release at least 1 fun color or something bold on the Pro. Like Pro people cannot have a bit of fun? Its insane. The white is also quite nice its actually like white not some creamy off white like the 15 pro max was
column37: but like true Apple white. The other colors are meh. If you like Black that is closer to pure black or the Space Black MacBook Pro. Camera / Button: I dont really use my camera that much
column38: but it's definitely top notch. But so was the 15Pro Max so what are we really gaining here? I feel like these have become more professional cameras and everything is like a side show. That's fine for the pro photographers but I feel like they are missing people that do other things on their phones. The button is meh. It's cool to capture photos relatively quickly but it's positioned weird so your mileage may vary and the scroll thing on is too gimmicky to futz with for me anyway. If you have a case on make sure you get one that supports it or you may not be able to access the button properly and it will drive you nuts. iOS 18: Again it's OK
column39: I feel like iOS is getting to be bloated. The bottom bar is different in many apps and it drives me nuts particularly on the Max. Even the new you can place icons anywhere is still half baked. And the setup is a hot mess! I dont know who tested that nightmare ugh but I recommend doing the encrypted backup to get started. Phone to Phone is a joke this year. The lack of multitasking on the Max is also a huge missed opportunity. The screen is huge but you cannot do anything different from the smaller one? Like what. that just doesn't make sense. Battery: Exceptional! This thing lasts forever. Compared to iPhone 16 Pro: I got the regular Pro first to see if the 6.3 would be good enough since I had a max for years but they are just so heavy I got sick of them. I tried for a few days and it was lighter but still quite dense so the weight savings were not that great overall. The max weighs a bit more but its spread over a larger area so feels less dense and therefore feels lighter. Still they are both heavy. The 16Pro is nice but the 6.3 is just still too small sadly. Hopefully the 6.5 iPhone 17 is the goldilocks with hopefully 120MHz and nice colors.
